questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of weight loss, bloating, and diarrhea. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows bilateral white spots on the temporal half of the conjunctiva, dry skin, and a hard neck mass in the anterior midline that does not move with swallowing. Urinalysis after a D-xylose meal shows a normal increase in renal D-xylose excretion. Which of the following would have been most likely to prevent this patient's weight loss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A gluten-free diet is the treatment of celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder involving hypersensitivity to gliadin in gluten. Celiac disease can also present with weight loss, diarrhea, bloating, and cutaneous manifestations, as in this patient. However, instead of xeroderma, skin manifestations include papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces (dermatitis herpetiformis). The D-xylose test would also have shown decreased xylose excretion due to damage of the intestinal mucosa. Celiac disease would also not explain this patient's hard anterior neck mass.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's hard, immobile neck mass in the anterior midline is suggestive of Riedel thyroiditis, which is associated with other IgG4-related systemic diseases. Vitamin A deficiency along with her weight loss, diarrhea, and physiologic increase in urinary D-xylose excretion indicate exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, most likely due to autoimmune pancreatitis. Pancreatic enzyme replacement would be the preventative treatment.

Because absorption of D-xylose in the intestine does not rely on the breakdown by pancreatic enzymes, a normal increase in urinary D-xylose excretion indicates a healthy intestinal mucosa. In conditions associated with damage to the intestinal mucosa, oral administration of D-xylose will result in increased fecal D-xylose excretion.

C) INCORRECT:

A therapy regimen of tetracycline in combination with folic acid would be a treatment of tropical sprue. This condition can cause diarrhea and a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin A. However, it is unlikely to manifest with an anterior neck mass or a normal result on the D-xylose test since it would be associated with damage to the intestinal mucosa. Tropical sprue would also more likely present following travel to the tropics.

D) INCORRECT:

Mesalamine therapy is a treatment for ulcerative colitis, which can cause chronic diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss, as in this patient. However, it does not manifest with an anterior neck mass or normal findings on the D-xylose test since it is associated with damage to the intestinal mucosa. Instead of Bitot's spots, expected ophthalmologic findings would be uveitis or episcleritis.

E) INCORRECT:

A lactose-free diet would prevent symptoms in patients with lactose intolerance, which is caused by lactase deficiency. Lactose intolerance manifests with diarrhea and a normal result of the D-xylose test, as in this patient. However, the symptoms only follow the consumption of dairy products. The condition is also not associated with either an anterior neck mass or a deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins like vitamin A.
questions.hint: This patient has xeroderma and keratin deposits on the conjunctivae (Bitot spots), which are features suggestive of vitamin A deficiency. The physiologic increase in D-xylose excretion seen in this patient indicates that the integrity of the intestinal mucosa is intact.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. She also has a history of lower back pain treated with ibuprofen. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (169 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry skin, swelling of the lower extremities, and a hard nontender anterior neck swelling that does not move with swallowing. Femoral and pedal pulses are decreased bilaterally. A biopsy of the neck swelling is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Atypical nuclei and concentric lamellar calcifications
Spindle cells and areas of focal necrosis
Collagen deposition and decreased number of follicles
Lymphocytic infiltrate and germinal center formation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psammoma bodies (characterized by concentric lamellar calcifications) and Orphan Annie eyes nuclei are histopathologic findings associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma. While patients with papillary thyroid carcinoma may present with a firm, immobile, and painless thyroid mass and symptoms of local compression (e.g., dysphonia and/or dysphagia), symptoms of hypothyroidism and retroperitoneal fibrosis are not associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid tissue sample (H&E stain; high magnification)

Psammoma bodies are concentric lamellar calcifications that are often seen within papillary thyroid carcinomas.

Other tumors with frequent presence of psammoma bodies include serous carcinoma of the ovary, high-grade serous carcinoma of the uterus, and meningiomas.

B) INCORRECT:

The most frequently seen histopathology in anaplastic thyroid carcinoma involves spindle cells and giant cells. Since anaplastic thyroid carcinomas grow so rapidly, areas of focal necrosis are often seen due to lack of blood supply. While patients with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma may present with a firm, immobile, and painless thyroid mass and signs of local compression (e.g. dysphonia and/or dysphagia), signs of hypothyroidism and retroperitoneal fibrosis are not associated with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fine-needle aspiration from a thyroid lesion (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Highly pleomorphic cells (examples indicated by blue overlay) with enlarged, irregular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli (examples indicated by arrows) are visible. Multinucleated tumor cells (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can also be seen. There are no follicular or papillary growth patterns.

The diagnosis of an anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a diagnosis of exclusion. This patient's diagnosis was supported by immunohistochemical findings (negative for TTF-1, thyroglobulin, and calcitonin).

C) CORRECT:

Chronic inflammation and collagen deposition (resulting in fibrosis) can lead to the destruction of thyroid follicles in patients with Riedel thyroiditis. If the fibrosis extends beyond the thyroid capsule into surrounding tissues, the swelling will be nonmobile and can lead to symptoms of local compression like hoarseness and dysphagia. Patients with Riedel thyroiditis are typically euthyroid, but about one-third of patients develop features of hypothyroidism (e.g., dry skin, weight gain). Riedel's thyroiditis is often associated with other IgG4-related diseases, such as retroperitoneal fibrosis or autoimmune pancreatitis.

There is no universal standard of treatment for Riedel thyroiditis. Medical treatment with corticosteroids +/- tamoxifen may reduce the size of the mass or slow down the progression of fibrosis. If the compressive symptoms are severe and not alleviated with medical therapy, debulking surgery may be indicated.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an enlarged thyroid specimen (H&E stain; high magnification)

Extensive fibrosis (examples indicated by blue overlay) with no intact thyroid follicles can be seen. There is a scattered lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate (examples indicated by yellow overlay) within the fibrotic stroma. Additionally, lymphocytic inflammation (examples indicated by arrows) in the walls of trapped veins can be seen.

The replacement of normal thyroid tissue with fibrosis is characteristic of Riedel thyroiditis (invasive fibrous thyroiditis).

D) INCORRECT:

Giant cells and noncaseating granulomas in a thyroid biopsy are consistent with subacute granulomatous thyroiditis. While patients with this condition may have thyroid swelling and may develop features of hypothyroidism (following transient hyperthyroidism), they typically present with a tender thyroid and have a history of recent viral or mycobacterial infection. Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis would also not explain the decreased pedal pulses.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a thyroid biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

A noncaseating granuloma composed of inflammatory cells (examples indicated by white arrowheads) engulfing colloid (acellular, pink, glassy substance; green overlay), numerous multinucleated giant cells (examples indicated by blue overlay), and a rim of fibrous tissue (yellow overlay) can be seen in the center of the image. The follicles in the region of the granuloma have been destroyed. Normal thyroid follicles (examples indicated by black arrowheads) are visible on the left.

This granulomatous destruction of thyroid tissue is characteristic of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis).

E) INCORRECT:

A lymphocytic infiltrate may be seen in Riedel thyroiditis due to chronic inflammation, but germinal centers do not form in this condition. Rather, germinal center formation combined with diffuse lymphocytic infiltration is characteristic of Hashimoto thyroiditis and Graves disease. While some of this patient's clinical features are consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis (painless thyroid enlargement, hypothyroid symptoms, nonspecific myalgias such as backache) or Graves disease (e.g., painless thyroid enlargement, pretibial myxedema), neither of these two conditions would explain the decreased pedal pulses. Also, the patient does not have the hyperthyroidism or exophthalmos that are associated with Graves disease.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of thyroid tissue (H&E stain)

The thyroid tissue in the lower half of the image is inflamed, as evidenced by the lymphocytic infiltrate (numerous purple dots) and dilated, congested blood vessels (examples indicated by arrows). Prominent lymphoid follicles with a germinal center (example indicated by orange overlay) surrounded by a hypercellular parafollicular region (example indicated by green overlay) are visible in the inflamed region. Normal thyroid follicles (example indicated by blue overlay) are visible in the top half of the image but are absent in the inflamed region.

Lymphocytic infiltration, lymphoid follicles with germinal centers, and destruction of thyroid follicles are characteristic features of Hashimoto thyroiditis.
questions.hint: A hard fixed anterior neck swelling with features suggestive of retroperitoneal fibrosis (decreased lower limb pulsations, low backache, lower limb swelling) indicates Riedel thyroiditis.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with hypertension, type 2 diabetes, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and recurrent idiopathic pancreatitis is seen in the emergency department for left flank pain that came on gradually during the past 3 days. He has generally been feeling unwell, noting a 4.5-kg weight loss during the past month and intermittent low-grade fevers. On review of systems, he also reports dry mouth, facial fullness, and diminished urinary frequency but no hesitation, dribbling, or pain with urination.
On examination, he is afebrile with a blood pressure of 168/92 mm Hg and a heart rate of 90 beats per minute. His face is full, and he has parotid enlargement. Cardiac and pulmonary examination is unremarkable. Abdominal examination reveals slight costovertebral angle tenderness on the left. The prostate is not enlarged on rectal examination.
Laboratory testing is notable for a blood urea nitrogen level of 50 mg/dL (reference range, 10–20), a serum creatinine level of 3.2 mg/dL (0.8–1.3), and a lipase level of 156 U/liter (0–160). The comprehensive metabolic panel and complete blood count are otherwise within normal limits, as are the urinalysis and sediment.
Renal ultrasound is without calculi but identifies a hypoechoic, periaortic mass with extension to both ureters, causing bilateral hydronephrosis. CT of the abdomen reveals a concentric soft-tissue mass surrounding the infrarenal abdominal aorta with extension to both ureters, although it is more constrictive on the left than on the right.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to yield a diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: CT-guided biopsy with immunohistochemical staining for plasma cells and immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positron emission tomography may be positive in a patient with IgG4-related disease. However, it is nonspecific and, in the absence of biopsy, would not be diagnostic.

B) INCORRECT:

Retrograde pyelography may confirm the presence of ureteral compression and allow for therapeutic intervention but would not be diagnostic of IgG4-related disease.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has an obstructive uropathy secondary to a diffuse, retroperitoneal fibrosis in the setting of constitutional symptoms, recurrent pancreatitis, and parotitis on physical examination. Taken together, these findings are suggestive of immunoglobulin G4 (IgG4)-related retroperitoneal fibrosis.

IgG4-related disease is a heterogenous group of immune-mediated conditions that can affect an isolated organ or be systemic. The most common manifestation is retroperitoneal fibrosis, which often causes a periaortitis with periureteral masses and ureteral compression. Other commonly affected organs include the pancreas, causing pancreatitis, as well as the salivary glands and thyroid.

No single test is specific for the diagnosis of IgG4-related disease. IgG4 levels are not always elevated in the serum of affected patients, and elevated IgG4 levels are not exclusive to this disease. Therefore, although serum IgG4 levels can be helpful, a biopsy is generally recommended when there is clinical suspicion. A finding of a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate that stains positive for IgG4 would be consistent with IgG4-related disease. Of note, positive staining for IgG4 can be seen in other disorders, and a biopsy result should therefore be interpreted in the full clinical context.

Key learning point: Obstructive uropathy with a periaortic mass in a patient with a history of pancreatitis or salivary disease should raise suspicion for immunoglobulin G4–related disease.

D) INCORRECT:

IgG4-related disease can cause sclerosing cholangitis, but this is not part of the patient’s current presentation, and no biliary abnormalities were seen on CT to suggest this possibility; therefore, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is less likely to be diagnostic.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a reported history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a prostate biopsy is not indicated to evaluate this condition, and it would be unusual for this condition to cause obstructive uropathy. BPH would also not explain his other imaging findings. A prostate biopsy can be helpful in making the diagnosis of prostate cancer, but this also rarely causes obstructive uropathy and rarely metastasizes to the retroperitoneal area. Therefore, a prostate biopsy is not indicated. The patient’s diminished urinary output is likely related to obstructive uropathy from the ureteral obstruction.
